The program supports short term, informal and jobrelated training. In 1988/89 only, the program also includes some Grants for Aboriginal Advancement-General Training projects, which cover a, range of Aboriginal community and individual training. This program element, which predates the AEDP, is due to cease on 30 June 1989. Four major departures from pre-, vious approaches are fundamental to the Government's strategy. These are: (I) to negotiate group training and recruitment packages; (2) to. ensure -hat training placements are only made when the prospects for recruitment after the training period are high; (3) to abolish standard on-thejob training subsidies under TAP and make all placements on a Negotiated Fee Basis; (4) to link the numbers of placements made to the target already identified as that required to achieve equity in Aboriginal employment in the public sector. The overall emphasis on T Anow is to ensure permanent employment after the training period. Description Cost$ Contract Employment A discrete part of the ADEP Program funded through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy is an employment and training scheme to increase Aboriginal involvement in Vertebrate Pest and Feral Animal Control and in the game meat industries. Funding for these schemes has been approved, under the Aboriginal Contract Employment Scheme, for an initial period of four years. The Scheme will provide for increased Aboriginal employment by: (a) developing Aboriginal employment strategies with State Vertebrate Pest Authorities on the necessary employment infrastructure to ensure that long term Aboriginal employment occurs; (b) developing mechanisms to achieve improved Aboriginal employment either on a contract or full time employment basis in the Commercial Harvesting and Game Meat Industries; (c) establishing the means for increasing the number of Aboriginal enterprises, in remote areas, in the Commercial Harvesting and Game Meat Industries. theText: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER ( Mr LeoDelegation report Statements upon presentation Parliamentary Report Delegation to the European Parliamentary Institutions 1988 [The Selection Committee has determined that statements on the report may be made-all statements to be made within a total time of 30 minutes.] Private Members' business Order of precedence Item Time allotted *1 MR KERR: To move-That this House: 40 minutes (I) accepts responsibility for its contribution to development of the existing social milieu within the Australian Public Service (APS) which has been variously described in Public Service Commission reports as "toxic, fearbased, pathological, repressive, reactive, paternalistic and neurotic" to the extent that some APS departments are seen as presenting the same manic depressive mental disorder symptoms which individuals present; (2) acknowledges that the manner in which Parliament seeks to maintain principles of fairness, impartiality, probity and public accountability is too often characterised by the use of its powers to seek punishment of those who are seen to have made mistakes, regardless of any consideration of risks involved, rather than to acknowledge and reward success; (3) notes that this hyper-critical approach is at variance with contemporary personnel management practices; and (4) acknowledges the serious efforts currently being made to implement improved management practices in the public sector and resolves to follow that lead by hencewith adopting a co-operative and constructive approach to its management of the Australian Public Service. (Notice given 25 May 1989. . *2 MR DOWNER: To move-That this House urges Australian business to 35 minutes address the implications for itself and the Australian economy in general of European economic integration post 1992. (Notice given 16 August 1989.) *3 MR COBB: To move-That, in the light of the joint select committee report any remaining on video pornography and violence being finalised, the Government should private recognise the urgent need to present legislation to stop the importation into Members' Australia of X-rated and excessively violent videos.
